title: Departure Den Helder
summary: The K-XVIII departed on 14 November 1934 from the Dutch Navy harbor in Den Helder to commence the longest solo mission for a submarine. On board was prof. Vening Meinesz.

title: Founder of NWO
summary: Vening Meinesz was one of the founders of NWO. Thanks to his international network and experiences, the professor saw the possibilities of governmental funding in the scientific world.

title: Gravity Explained
summary: The goal of Vening Meinesz was to measure the gravity field of the Earth. What is gravity and why does it differ on various locations.

title: Aboard K-XVIII
summary: The crewmembers on board the K-XVIII had to live in a cramped submarine for eight months. This meant they had to adjust to each other and the circumstances.

title: Isostasy Explained
summary: Vening Meinesz discovered, during his many expeditions that the strength of the crust is partially responsible for supporting mountains and continents.

title: Crossing of the Snip
summary: One of the objectives of the K-XVIII was to be a navigational beacon for KLM's first trans-continental postal flight. Thanks to the K-XVIII it could safely cross the Atlantic Ocean.

title: Plate Tectonics
summary: The theory of plate tectonics was not yet accepted by the academic society during Vening Meinesz time. He did not believe in it, but his observations tell a different story.

title: Neptune's Ritual
summary: Crossing the equator with a ship could attract the god of the ocean to come aboard. Neptune and his wife visited the K-XVIII, when they crossed the equator on the 11th of January 1935.

title: Romanche Trench
summary: The Romanche Trench is a so-called transform fault and is more than seven km deep. It is located between Africa and South America.

title: Showing the Flag
summary: During this time the reputation of the Dutch Navy was very low among the Dutch citizens. The Navy used this expedition to improve this reputation in the Netherlands.

title: Biography Vening Meinesz
summary: Professor Vening Meinesz has achieved a lot during his life. His dedication to science played a major role in his life and he has influenced many scientists throughout the world.

title: K-XVIII Submarine
summary: Thanks to an incredible design and engineering of the K-XVIII, this vessel was able to sail the Earth's oceans and complete a trip of 23,000 miles.

title: Diving Procedure
summary: The crewmembers aboard the K-XVIII performed diving procedures three times a day, on average. These procedures were performed by at least one third of the crew.

title: Spreading Ridge
summary: The spreading ridge is an important aspect in plate tectonics. Vening Meinesz measured the gravity effect of several of these ridges during the voyage with the K-XVIII.

title: Tristan da Cunha
summary: Tristan da Cunha is a volcanic island situated in the middle of the South Atlantic Ocean. On the island is a British settlement, which is one of the most remote places to live.

title: Hotspot Volcanism
summary: Hotspot volcanism is one of the three types of volcanism found on Earth. The source for these volcanoes is found in the deep layers of the mantle.

title: Gravity Compared
summary: Vening Meinesz' incredible work is best shown when compared to gravity observations from modern-day satellite observations.

title: Stay at Cape Town
summary: After a long and stormy stretch over the South Atlantic Ocean, the K-XVIII finally arrived in Cape Town. The crew and the professor were greatly welcomed.

title: Pendulum Apparatus
summary: Vening Meinesz had designed the pendulum apparatus in 1921 to remove vertical motions from the observations. This invention allowed measuremnts of the gravity field on the oceans.

title: Calibration and Time
summary: The cause of his precise measurements of the gravity field is the numerous calibrations Vening Meinesz performed in the years before his expeditions.

title: Depth Measurements
summary: The K-XVIII had sonar equipment on board for measuring the depth of the ocean floor, essential for Vening Meinesz studies. They revealed many secrets of the deep oceans.

title: Comite Onze Marine
summary: The citizens of the Netherlands were excited by the long voyage of the K-XVIII. They started a comity to help the crew during the entire expedition.

title: Troubles Onboard
summary: In contrast with the reports from the movie and media, the mood onboard the K-XVIII wasn't always excellent. There were some arguments between the professor and the captain.

title: Location Finding
summary: To determine the position of the K-XVIII, the navigation officer would use a sextant to measure different angles between celestial objects.

title: Geoid Explained
summary: Geodesy is the study that is responsible for measuring the shape of the Earth. One of their biggest concerns is the definition of 0 meter height, or sea level.

title: Stay at Fremantle
summary: Many Australians came to see the K-XVIII when it arrived in Fremantle. The professor visited the University of West Australia, where he made an observation of the gravity field.

title: Holweck-Lejay
summary: The Golden Calf was too big and heavy to quickly take on land, so Vening Meinesz had acquired a Holweck-Lejay gravimeter from the "Bataafsche Petrolium Maatschappij" to perform land measurements.

title: Chronometers
summary: Professor Vening Meinesz needed accurate timekeeping during his voyage for his precise gravity measurements, so he brought the best clocks available with him.

title: Subduction Zone
summary: At the end of the journey of the K-XVIII they sailed over a subduction zone, which is, coincidentally, also the location of the end-of-life of an oceanic plate.

title: Reception at Surabaya
summary: After eight months of sailing the oceans of the Earth, the K-XVIII with professor Vening Meinesz arrived at the final port, Surabaya, where a large crowd awaited them.
